content: Thinking more on the random merge date... we have access to timestamps so we *could* assert that the merge will happen on the first block after UTC 14:00 on a random day.

author: sky.cactus
content: Developers would have to "watch for The Merge" every day, but at least it would be for a limited period of time each day.

author: sky.cactus
content: We could even say that it will always be on a Wednesday pretty easily.

author: sky.cactus
content: So every Wednesday everyone would watch for the first block with a 14:00 timestamp to see if The Merge happens.

author: sky.cactus
content: One caveat here is that miners could specifically avoid publishing any block they mine that would lead to the random block selection system deciding it is the merge block.  This assumes that the blockhash is part of the random selection which I think is necessary unfortunately.

content: That'd be better in the case of random date selection. But we can't make the selection period too long, even a month would be too long, right? And if there is an announcement that the merge happens during the next month but we don't know when exactly it would not save us from miners preparing 51% attack or making a fork. It would only address the "last miner" problem but it could be addressed without randomizing the point of merge, by e.g. deferring the decision on the block to the beacon chain.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think if the random selection period is long *enough* then it addresses other miner attack vectors (like double spends).

content: As an extreme example, if the period was 1 year I don't think miners would burn a years worth of income out of malice.

content: ðŸ¤” Actually, maybe <@144468805697929216> is right here.  The real incentive not to attack is because you have a source of future-ETH, not that you are working for it.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you have Ethereum mining hardware, you have a "source of future ETH" so you don't attack the network today because you don't want to burn your future ETH.

author: sky.cactus
content: If someone asked, "can I rent your hashing power at a 10% premium for an hour so I can use it to attack Ethereum" most miners would say no, because that hurts the future-value of their mining hardware.

author: sky.cactus
content: So, if we pick a bunch of people who have mining hardware and we tell them, "we'll give you X ETH in a year" they have incentive to try to keep ETH's price high for at least a year.

author: agusx1211
content:
They could still gamble it thinking the attack is not going to be successful, it's a prisoners dilemma, from the individual perspective it's always better to get the free rewards and attack the network.
Maintaining the PoW requires the hardware to be occupied, and not be available for an attack at all.

author: sky.cactus
content: It certainly isn't as strong as a guarantee, since having them do PoW, since they could sell their hardware (to a potential attacker) not realizing that it could hurt their future assets.

The miners need to *trust* that the core developers/holders/users will not rug pull them after The Merge.  We essentially are entering into a nonbinding agreement with a service provider where we have the power to nullify the contract after services are rendered.
